Class Cost

java.lang.Object
WorkLoad.Cost
public class Cost extends Object
Represents a scheduling-related cost (delay) that affects a core while a requested job or migration is being processed.

A Cost encapsulates the core currently affected (`curCore`), the core that requested the action (`requestCore`), the Job that triggered the cost (`requestJob`), the cost type (`status` - e.g. CONTEXTSWITCH or MIGRATION), an optional linked nextCost (used when a context switch precedes a migration), and the remaining costTime in internal time units.

Inline comments present in the original file are integrated here: the Chinese comments explain that `curCore` is the current core, `requestCore` is the core that caused the cost, and `requestJob` is the job that caused the cost. The class is used by the simulator's cost queue to track and apply context-switch and migration delays.

Author:
YC

  • Constructor Details

    • Cost

      public Cost(Core curCore, Core requestCore, Job requestJob, Definition.CoreStatus status)
      Create a new Cost describing a delay affecting curCore caused by an action from requestCore on behalf of requestJob.

      The constructor sets the cost type and initializes the remaining costTime according to the current simulator settings. For Definition.CoreStatus.CONTEXTSWITCH the cost time is set to the simulator's context switch time; for Definition.CoreStatus.MIGRATION it is set to the simulator's migration time. Other statuses leave costTime at zero unless modified later.

      Parameters:
      curCore - the core that will experience the cost (current core)
      requestCore - the core that initiated the request causing the cost
      requestJob - the job that caused this cost
      status - the type of cost (e.g. CONTEXTSWITCH or MIGRATION)

  • Method Details

    • execution

      public void execution(long time)
      Advance the execution of this cost by the specified time amount.

      This subtracts time from the remaining costTime. Callers (typically the simulator's time-stepping loop) should invoke this to reduce the outstanding delay; once costTime reaches zero the cost is considered completed and checkIsCompleted() can be used to apply completion side-effects.

      Parameters:
      time - the amount of time to consume from this cost (in same units as costTime)

    • setNextCost

      public void setNextCost(Cost migrationCost)
      Link a subsequent cost to be processed after this one completes.

      This method is used for the migration workflow where a context-switch cost may be followed immediately by a migration cost. Linking the migration Cost via nextCost ensures the simulator can properly sequence and handle both delays.

      Parameters:
      migrationCost - the Cost to execute after this Cost completes

    • getCurrentCore

      public Core getCurrentCore()
      Return the core currently affected by this cost.
      Returns:
      the current Core that experiences the delay

    • getRequestCore

      public Core getRequestCore()
      Return the core that requested the action causing this cost.
      Returns:
      the requesting Core

    • getRequestJob

      public Job getRequestJob()
      Return the job that triggered this cost.
      Returns:
      the Job responsible for this cost

    • getStatus

      public Definition.CoreStatus getStatus()
      Return the cost type/status.
      Returns:
      the CoreStatus categorizing this cost

    • setCostTime

      public void setCostTime(long time)
      Explicitly set the remaining cost time.
      Parameters:
      time - the remaining cost time to assign (in same units as the simulator uses)

    • checkIsCompleted

      public boolean checkIsCompleted()
      Check whether this cost has completed and apply completion side-effects.

      When the internal costTime reaches zero this method applies the appropriate actions depending on the cost status:

      • For Definition.CoreStatus.CONTEXTSWITCH: if there is no nextCost it ensures the requestJob is set as the working job on its current core (avoiding redundant set operations). If a linked nextCost exists, it will only take effect after that cost also completes (the method checks nextCost.checkIsCompleted()).
      • For Definition.CoreStatus.MIGRATION: if the requestCore equals curCore the method enqueues the requestJob on the request core's local ready queue and updates the job's current core reference.
      The method returns true when this Cost is finished (and can be removed from the simulator's cost queue); otherwise it returns false. Callers are responsible for removing completed costs from the queue.
      Returns:
      true if the cost is completed and completion effects were applied; false otherwise
